page.title: 13Crofting.
page.content: The high land in our area is generally good hill grazing and the low land is very well fertilised and is good growing land. The high land is also mainly heathery and stoney. We interviewed Cathy Williamson who said,when we asked her about how many sheep she had in the area,that it all depended on how severe the winter was because she could lose a lot of sheep or in a mild winter she might only lose two or three sheep.When we asked her about how she worked with the sheep she told us that they had to be dipped in sheep dip,they also had to be clipped , they have to be dosed, marked with clips in their ears - these are called lug marks. In the spring time they have to deal with the strains of the lambing. Crops grown include,potatoes (tatties), turnips (neeps) and cabbage (keel).
